intro: Coronopus heleniana, commonly known as the Greek bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue or violet flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or limestone soils and thrives in full sun. It has lance-shaped leaves and produces small, clustered flowers that bloom in summer. Due to its ornamental value and limited distribution, it is often cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
